body.name: Dark Angel (A Letty Davenport Novel Book 2)
body.description: Letty Davenport, the tough-as-nails adopted daughter of Lucas Davenport, takes on an undercover assignment that brings her across the country and into the crosshairs of a dangerous group of hackers.Letty Davenport’s days working a desk job at are behind her. Her previous actions at a gunfight in Texas—and her incredible skills with firearms—draw the attention of several branches of the US government, and make her a perfect fit for even more dangerous work. The Department of Homeland Security and the NSA have tasked her with infiltrating a hacker group, known only as Ordinary People, that is intent on wreaking havoc. Letty and her reluctant partner from the NSA pose as free-spirited programmers for hire and embark on a cross country road trip to the group’s California headquarters.While the two work to make inroads with Ordinary People and uncover their plans, they begin to suspect that the hackers are not their only enemy. Someone within their own circle may have betrayed them, and has ulterior motives that place their mission—and their lives—in grave danger. Read more

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 26, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I have read most of John's books, but lately I have moved on to Amazon Prime books. I read the first Letty book and decided to try this one. As I approach middle age, I have found that my concentration has been failing. I read a few pages of a book and return to it later. I found this book to be so fast paced that I couldn't put it down! Very well written, great characters, and action. I hope that there's another Letty book coming.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 9, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Didn’t grab as well as the first because I’m seriously not into Russian stuff of any kind and still don’t quite understand why it got to where it did, but that’s just me. Clever to bring the war straight into it. Loved the characters, especially Baxter who I’m sure we will hear more from, and glad to see Cartwright still around. Still with the quick sharp tongue and wit, that fine balance is always there, it just didn’t exceed any expectations.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2024
reviews.reviewText: I really like John Sanford. I have read just about everything he’s written. He has action and suspense in his books and always a great plot.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 8, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Excellent! I was on the edge of my seat the entire book

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 26, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars An excellent read
reviews.reviewText: In light of current events, this book is most timely. It does leave you wondering if the opposition were assisted in their incompetence.....

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 29, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars Letty Davenport Returns
reviews.reviewText: This is the second Letty Davenport novel. The character is a spin off from the Lucas Davenport “Prey” series. That series, over thirty books now, was, until quite recently five star quality. That’s for another review. Any of the series can be read as a stand-alone. I’ve enjoyed each from the onset of the series.Anyway, Lucas Davenport began as a Minneapolis Police Detective. Then an Agent of the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension. Most recently, a free lance Deputy U.S. Marshal. He and his team rescued Letty from a horrific child abuse ring. Then he and his wife adopted her. Letty is very, very tough and as a teenager shoots dead two home invaders bent on murdering her adoptive family..Then, her series begins. She is a twenty something aide to a very influential Senator and an investigator for a Senate Committee. She is armed, partnered with a retired special operations soldier and tasked with looking into missing oil. This leads to a harrowing chase ending in a confrontation with militia types at the Mexican border. A bit out there, but still quite good.In this book, she is now a credentialed Special Agent of the Homeland Security Department Inspector General.Partnered with a female CIA Officer, and a male computer nerd employed by NSA, she is tasked with identifying a group of hackers who disrupted the Russian rail system in the run up to the invasion of Ukraine. She locates the hackers, now pursued by extraordinarily incompetent Russian government killers. There is a lot of very implausible action and eventually a satisfactory resolution.Sandford’s strengths are character development (especially sociopaths) and dialogue.Weaknesses. I am a retired prosecutor. In this genre, I look for authenticity. Not Jack Webb/Joe Friday dialogue…but at least plausibility. These characters move from gun fight to gunfight, shooting villains, most of whom, in fairness, need shooting. And then just move on with no consequences. And insert themselves into situations that even most TV scriptwriters know would result in multi-agency, super sized investigations. And, again, the villains are just so very incompetent.I gave it three stars because the plot moves. There are some very well executed segments. But, it’s wildly implausible and way too long. And, disappointing to me because John Sandford has done so much better in so many prior novels.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars At last, Letty is the star!
reviews.reviewText: John Sandford introduced a slightly feral girl to his Prey series. Letty West was a half-starved pre-teen with an alcoholic mother and serious survival skills. Over time, she became the adopted daughter of Lucas Davenport, the protagonist of that series. As she grew older, she was involved in a variety of mayhem and murder, and I always thought she deserved her own series. Here it is. Letty is well-educated, very smart, and just as tough as ever. She's ready to make her mark in law enforcement and starts out with a bang. My only complaint is that Letty had dark blond hair in the Prey books, but now has brown hair, which is jarring. Sandford hits the mark on how a woman's character can be shaped by childhood trauma; Letty's personality suits what we already know of her.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 21, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars cocked and locked
reviews.reviewText: a truly contemporary believable story line. focused on screwing up Russian invasion of Ukraine..Letty doesn’t disappoint!new character introduced also
Tries to make it funny , it does not work. It’s almost slapstick comedy hour , the base of the story was good , to bad.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on November 7, 2023
reviews.reviewText: One of the best and most enjoyable and entertaining books I’ve read for some time. The key characters are fascinating and very likeable and the storyline is very engaging and moves along with pace. Can’t wait for Letty’s third assignment.
Sandford does it again with a damn great book. Action packed and very well told. Can't wait to reread it or and for the series to continue.

I was a little leery of Letty Davenports’ arrival in the Sandford lexicon, but I worried needlessly: what a cracking yarn!Letty is a most worthy protagonist, and is a character that is going to develop very nicely indeed - she is likeable, capable and good at what she does, so all good there!I like John Kaisers’ character very much, too; every main character needs a dependable sidekick, and Kaiser is certainly that.I thought the Ladies were an interesting spin, too, and - I have to say - a most welcome addition to the story… in short, I like this new direction very much indeed and look forwarc to reading more of her adventures!
